title: Hello World
text:
Hello World
The below python code takes the phrase “Hello World!” and prints it to the console. It’s a good way to check you are set up correctly!

title: Set up
text:
We are going to use Python for this course. You can do this on campus from a University Computer, online using a free Google Colab account that you can access from any web browser, or by downloading Python and Visual Studio Code onto your own device.
Click below to see the set up instructions for each:

University ComputerOnline CloudOwn Device


To get set up, follow the below steps. Click each step for detailed instructions.






Step 1: Launch Visual Studio Code from AppsAnywhere






Type in AppsAnywhere to the windows bar. This will open in a web browser
Open the following two applications by typing the name in and clicking launch:

Python
Visual Studio Code





GIF of Opening VSCode











Step 2: Navigate to your OneDrive folder






Click “Open Folder” on the loading screen
Find your OneDrive folder. You should be able to recognise the files and folders listed, from what you have saved here in your other classes.
Create a new folder for this python course, and open this folder.




GIF of Opening OneDrive folder











Step 3: Install the python extension






Click the extensions tab
Search and install python




GIF of Making a Folder











Step 4: Create and run a Python file





You’re now ready to run some Python code!

Go back to your folder
Click the “New file” button
Give your file a name ending .py (e.g. “Test.py” )
Add the following line to your file


print("Hello World")


Press the run button

And that’s it - you’re all set up!



GIF of making a python File








Warning





Make sure you can find your file in file explorer. Always back up your work such as saving in OneDrive or emailing to yourself so that you don’t lose your progress.








Google Colab is a free tool for running python on a browser - from a file saved in your Google Drive.






Caution





You shouldn’t need a paid account for this course. If your work becomes too large, then I suggest downloading and running Python and Visual Studio Code on your device.



To get set up, follow the instructions below:






Set up Google Colab notebook






Sign into Google with any Google account
Go to Google Colab
Click file -> New Notebook in Drive
Name your file (e.g “Test.ipynb”) The file is an Ipython Notebook so ends with .ipynb instead of .py
Add and run the following code:


print("Hello World")




GIF of creating a Google Colab notebook





And that’s it for setting up with Google Colab!


If you’re working on your own laptop or computer it’s also possible to download and run Python and Visual Studio Code. These are both free, open-source programs.






Note





If you’re working on a tablet, chromebook or your device is typically slow, I recommend looking at the Google Colab option instead



Installing Python and VSCode can be a bit fiddley - let the teaching team know if you’d like any support.
Why two programs? Python is the programming language, that takes our data and does our analyses. Visual Studio Code is a program we use to edit and run our python files. It’s a text editor that is specialised for coding projects.






Step 1: Install Python





You can Install Python from this website. It should automatically detect whether you are on a Windows or a Mac PC and suggest which version to download. Click download and then follow the installation instructions.



Screenshot of Python website











Step 2: Install Visual Studio Code





Once Python is installed, you can install Visual Studio Code from this website.
It should also automatically detect what type of PC you are on.



Screenshot of Visual Studio Code website











Step 3: Create or move to a folder for LS6036






Click “Open Folder” on the loading screen
Browse files until you can find your documents - wherever you keep your university files.
Create a new folder for this python course, and open this folder.




GIF of Opening OneDrive folder











Step 4: Install the python extension





Now we need to set up Visual Studio Code to recognise and use your version of python.

Click the extensions tab
Search and install python




GIF of Making a Folder











Step 5: Write and run a python file





You’re now ready to run some Python code!

Go back to your folder
Click the “New file” button
Give your file a name ending .py (e.g. “Test.py” )
Add the following line to your file


print("Hello World")


Press the run button

And that’s it - you’re all set up!



GIF of making a python File
